Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They face a serious situation that directly tests their commitment to Christian morals
Story: We were walking home from school, my stepbrother and I, chatting about nothing in particular. The street was quiet, the sun dipping low. Suddenly, a group of older kids blocked our path, laughing and jeering. One of them shoved my stepbrother, hard. My heart pounded. I remembered Mom’s words: “Look out for each other. You’re family now.” I wanted to protect him, to stand up and fight back. But then, another voice echoed in my mind—my Sunday school teacher, reminding us to turn the other cheek, to forgive, to show love even to those who hurt us. The boys taunted us, daring us to react. My stepbrother looked at me, fear and anger in his eyes, silently begging me to do something. I felt torn in two—my loyalty to him pulling me one way, my faith pulling me another. My fists clenched, my mind raced, and I stood frozen, caught between the urge to defend my brother and the call to live out my Christian values.
